dc:description:
PSEN1 was originally evaluated for DCM by the ClinGen DCM GCEP on September 25th, 2020. Evidence of the association of this gene with DCM was re-evaluated using SOP v10 on May 29th, 2025As a result, the classification did not change. A summary of the information contributing to the classification of this gene at the time of re-evaluation is summarized herein.

PSEN1 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) in 2006 (Li et al., 2006, PMID: 17186461). There is a lack of robust human genetic evidence demonstrating this gene-disease relationship in the literature at the time of curation. All of the variants reported as disease-causing have subsequently been found at a frequency higher than would be expected for a monogenic, pathogenic effect in population reference data sets. Therefore, there is no scorable human genetic evidence. This gene-disease assertion is supported by expression studies (Gianni et al., 2010, PMID: 2019488).

In summary, the evidence presented for this gene-disease relationship does not provide convincing human genetic evidence in support of or refuting the role of PSEN1 and DCM. The relationship of PSEN1 with DCM is unclear and therefore classified as disputed. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Dilated Cardiomyopathy Working Group on May 29th, 2025 (SOP Version 10).
curationReasonDescription: The DCM GCEP classified PSEN1 as disputed as there was no genetic evidence that could be scored.

member.rdfs:label: II.4
member.previousTestingDescription: LMNA, MYH7, TNNT2, SCN5A, CSRP3, PLN

evidence.dc:description: Allele frequency in African Ancestry in gnomAD v4 >0.01% and is not sufficiently rare to be causal for penetrant Mendelian disease. Functional evidence of this variant supports damaging impact to gene function, but does not support gene-disease relationship.
Calcium signaling was altered in cultured fibroblasts with PSEN1 missense mutation.

Western blotting for PSEN1 in healthy individuals and in DCM patients were analyzed. PS1 expression normalized by GAPDH in the patients carrying the genetic variations was 0.790.18 vs 0.9325 in the iDCM patients without the genetic variants (the level in the nonfailing population was 0.560.24); P=0.046, Kruskal-Wallis test. This evidence supports marginal evidence of enrichment in DCM samples.
evidence.rdfs:label: Western blot of DCM and control hearts

evidence.dc:description: No human genetic evidence supporting ATP2A2 in DCM
ATP2A2 and regulator PLN implicated in dilated cardiomyopathy in human genetic (PLN) and experimental evidence (ATP2A2).
evidence.rdfs:label: Co-immunoprecipitation

evidence.dc:description: The silencing of the fly ortholog of human PSEN1 was associated with a decreased ventricular size.
The comparison of dPsn siRNA silencing versus age-matched controls showed a reduction end-systolic vertical dimension, in contrast to ventricular dilatation observed in dilated cardiomyopathy.
evidence.rdfs:label: UAS-dPsn or UAS-dPsn-RNAi transgenic flies
